Proposing A Data Science Philosophy ğŸ’¬

Prefer remote + reproducible over local + manual
Code, not outputs, should be the source of truth
Narrate your thinking with notebooks
Track your work with Git
Save on technical debt by investing in robust systems

FASRC: Logging In & Launching RStudio ğŸš€

Get on the VPN
Go to the Open OnDemand site https://rcood.rc.fas.harvard.edu
Log in with FASRC Account details
Launch a RStudio Server session
Create and save an R file (You can also download the example file 1_FASRC_step4_example.r)

section: Workflow Benefit #1: Efficiency with High Performance Compute Clusters
text:
Workflow Benefit #1: Efficiency with High Performance Compute Clusters    

FASRC is a high performance computing resource whose professional responsibility is to save you (and your data) from yourself 4 5


OpenOnDemand sessions persist as long as the job is specified
File permissions mechanisms are specific and deliberate
Software will (likely) never crash due to a mistake on your part
You will (likely) never break FASRC

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text: Letâ€™s go back to our work from yesterdayâ€¦ wait, what was I doing againâ€¦?

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text:
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

model <- lm(mpg ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars)
new_data <- data.frame(wt = c(2.5, 3.0, 3.5), hp = c(100, 150, 200))
predictions <- predict(model, newdata = new_data)

plot <- ggplot(new_data, aes(x = wt, y = hp)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(predictions, 2)), vjust = -1, color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Predicted MPG based on Weight and Horsepower",
       x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
       y = "Horsepower")
print(plot)


---
title: "My fantastic analysis"
format: 
  html:
    self-contained: true
date: now
author: "Squidward P. Tentacles"
---

In this analysis I'm going to use the `mtcars` dataset to
demonstrate regression and prediction.

## Libraries

Here are the necessary libraries you'll need to replicate this...

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
```

## Fitting the model

I chose to use the `wt` an `hp` variables as predictors because blah blah blah...

```{r}
model <- lm(mpg ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars)
```

## Predict on New Data

I'm creating some new data to predict on...

```{r}
new_data <- data.frame(wt = c(2.5, 3.0, 3.5), hp = c(100, 150, 200))
predictions <- predict(model, newdata = new_data)
```

And plotting it with ggplot:
```{r}
plot <- ggplot(new_data, aes(x = wt, y = hp)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(predictions, 2)), vjust = -1, color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Predicted MPG based on Weight and Horsepower",
       x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
       y = "Horsepower")
plot
```

## Conclusion

In this notebook I ran an experiment and documented it so that next time
I or someone else sees it they can know exactly what I did
and why ğŸ˜

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text:
Literate Programming with NotebooksğŸ–¼ï¸

â€œğŸ’¡Documentation is like a love letter you write to your future selfâ€ (Damien Conway) 6


(Knuth, 1984 7) Literate programming is the intertwining of written and machine language to self-document and explain code.
A programâ€™s source code is made primarily to be read and understood by other people, and secondarily to be executed by the computer.
In data science, we use notebook tools like Quarto, RMarkdown, or JuPyter to combine narrative, code, and outputs

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text:

Notebooks provide narrative context, code, and outputs in one place
Enable others (and your future self) to understand and reproduce your work
Great for supervisor meetings, review, and sharing
Encourage â€œwriting as thinkingâ€

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
section: Organize Projects with here(), configs, and renv
text:
Organize Projects with here(), configs, and renv




Use here::here() instead of "../" or "~/Downloads/"


library(here)
here("data", "input.csv")



Use configs to manage paths outside of the project
Keeps paths portable and self-documenting
Helps build & maintain structured projects



default:
  data_dir: "/nfs/shared/data"
  results_dir: "/nfs/shared/results"
  madagascar:
      shapefile: "https://data.humdata.org/dataset/26fa506b-0727-4d9d-a590-d2abee21ee22/resource/ed94d52e-349e-41be-80cb-62dc0435bd34/download/mdg_adm_bngrc_ocha_20181031_shp.zip"


Use renv and/or conda to manage packages
Allows you to document exact package versions and dependencies for each project
Stores package metadata in a text file that can be version controlled and shared with your project

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
section: Workflow Benefit #3: Modularity with path & package managers 9 10
text:
Workflow Benefit #3: Modularity with path & package managers 9 10    

ğŸ‘¯ Collaboration: Modular code is easier for teams to understand, reuse, and extend.
How can you make your code more modular?

ğŸ§­ Portability of location: Use tools like here() to manage file and document paths
ğŸ— Portability of dependencies Use tools like renv or conda to manage package dependencies
ğŸ Portability of code components: Use functions and modules so that code can be reused and tested independently

ğŸ“ˆ Scalability: Modular workflows adapt easily to new data, collaborators, or computing environments.

text:
Itâ€™s time to publish your groundbreaking paper on the equivalence of glm and lm! Youâ€™ve run the analysis three times now: fantastic_analysis_v3.R, final_FINAL.Rmd, and FINAL_revised_with_comments_v2.qmd.




During a meeting, the PI asks:




â€œCan you show me what changed between the version we worked on 6 weeks ago and this one you sent me yesterday?â€

text:
Version Control with Git & GitHub 
Why Git?

Track every change you make
Recover and understand past versions
Collaborate without fear

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text:
Version Control with Git & GitHub 

Set up your GitHub Account with secure PATs (Personal Access Token = Special Password ğŸ˜‰) with usethis::create_github_token()
Initialize a git repository for your project with usethis::use_git()
Track some changes
â€œPushâ€ the changes to GitHub for backup and sharing with usethis::use_github()
Open GitHub to see your code reflected!



By far, the best resource for Git for R users is HappyGitWithR.com [^https://happygitwithr.com/hello-git]

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
section: Workflow Benefit #4: Traceability with Version Control 11 12
text:
Workflow Benefit #4: Traceability with Version Control 11 12    

No more file clutter: Replace final_v3_revised_REAL_FINAL.Rmd with clean version tracking
Precise change history: Git tracks edits line by line â€” you know what changed, when, and why.
Intentional work: Use git as a daily lab notebook where commits encourage reflection (what did I do today, and why?)
Safe collaboration: Work in parallel without overwriting each otherâ€™s code using branches and pull requests. Experimentation is encouraged
Work with the garage door up: Share your process early, even if itâ€™s not polished. GitHub lets collaborators see your progress and offer feedback or help sooner

section: I get it; itâ€™s a lot ğŸ˜°
text:
I get it; itâ€™s a lot ğŸ˜°


 13


Itâ€™s a learning process/investment with benefits accruing over time
Adopting these principles gradually is fine â€” start small, but start now.
These principles arenâ€™t about using fancy tools â€” theyâ€™re about creating systems that are beneficial to your future self and your collaborators.
Labs that adopt reproducible workflows produce cleaner, more sustainable+trustworthy science.

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text: Labs that donâ€™tâ€¦14

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text:
Reproducible collaboration requires compromise ğŸ¤

We want reproducibility.
They might want convenience.


You canâ€™t force everyone to use Git, FASRC, Quarto, etc. all the time


You can compromise â€” and still keep your workflow clean â€” by finding and implementing creative middle-ground solutions.


For e.g., the pins package ğŸ“Œ

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text:
Accessing Google Drive with pinsğŸ“Œ

Google Drive (and friends) donâ€™t neatly fit into the workflow (for reasons weâ€™ve discussed)
How do you share data with outside Harvard collaborators?ğŸ§
How do you couple your data science to other academic workflows?
pins solves this by providing versioned programmatic access to Google, Box, OneDrive etc.
Treats data objects in R/Python/Javascript as â€œpinsâ€ and online locations as â€œpinup boardsâ€

title: Reproducible Data Science Workflows in Climate-Smart Public Health ResearchğŸŒğŸ¤–ğŸ“Š
text:
Accessing Google Drive with pinsğŸ“Œ

Create a board in R from the Google Drive


install.packages("pins")
install.packages("googledrive")
drive_id <- googledrive::as_id("https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1MYoaffvU9ogu7nFo3Whz7XYVG1fq4wHY?usp=share_link")
board <- board_gdrive(drive_id, versioned=TRUE)


Create and write a pin for your glm() results


pin_write(board, salary_glm_model, name="glm results", "Showing that the glm results are identical to the lm results")

pins gives you:
